items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
On March 4, 2016, the District posted Request for Qualifications #1754 for Construction Testing and Special Inspection Services on the FHDA portal of the PlanetBids website. Responses were received on April 5, 2016. The RFQ sought construction testing and special inspection services from firms who are qualified to perform Project Inspector and Special Inspector services to the District on projects under the jurisdiction of the Division of the State Architect (DSA). In general, inspections include rebar, concrete, shotcrete, masonry, steel, wood, and other inspections as outlined in DSA-103 forms for each DSA project. Construction projects at the Foothill - De Anza Community College District campuses consist of site projects, infrastructure upgrades, new construction and renovation of existing buildings. As projects vary in size and complexity, the Special Inspector/s must effectively coordinate and cooperate with the District’s Inspector of Record, Architect(s), Construction Manager(s) and Contractor(s) assigned to the projects.
	 
Twelve firms responded to the Request for Qualifications:
         BAGG Engineers
         BSK Associates
         Consolidated Engineering Laboratories
         Construction Testing Services, Inc.
         CTE Cal, Inc.
         Earth Systems
         MatriScope Engineering Laboratories, Inc.
         Ninyo & Moore
         RMA Group
         Signet Testing Laboratories, Inc.
         Smith Emery San Francisco
         Structure Groups
	 
District facilities staff reviewed the responses of each applicant and determined that all eleven firms demonstrated the necessary experience and qualifications to provide at least some aspect of services desired by the District. Firms from this pool will be selected for individual projects based on their experience and qualifications specific to the project, the project needs, the firm’s staff availability and cost effectiveness. Firms may be selected from this list for up to five (5) years from the Board’s acceptance of this list.
	 
Submitted by:
 Steve Kitchen x6150
Additional contact names:
 Art Heinrich x6295, Tom Armstrong x8289
Is backup provided?

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Recent growth in international student enrollment is due primarily to our increased international student recruitment efforts and to the intensive development of formal relationships with private educational advising agencies around the world. These agents send students overseas to undertake their college and university study. Over the past eight years, we employed the services of this contractor, Gregory Barattini, who helped us to significantly increase the number of relationships we maintain with agents all over China, Indonesia, the rest of Southeast Asia and Europe. This expansion was a strong factor in past years in the District being able to increase international student enrollment  despite the very challenging economic environment. In addition, the contractor helped reduce the District's travel expenses by representing us at many international study abroad fairs and exhibitions.
	 
This contract would extend the services of Gregory Barattini for a one-year period starting July 1st. Mr. Barattini is a recognized professional expert and is one of few individuals known to the Foothill and De Anza International Programs Offices who provides this kind of international student recruitment representation to colleges and universities. For years, he worked as the senior vice president for marketing at several large international language school chains, recently represented Santa Monica College in a similar capacity over a four-year period, and has done an excellent job for Foothill-De Anza Community College District in past years. His clients also include Berkeley Colleges in New York City and UCLA Extension. He fully understands what the District has to offer and how to market us abroad, and is on a first-name  basis with a very large number of advising agents around the world. In addition, he is physically located in Indonesia, which allows him to travel inexpensively throughout the region and saves us considerable expenses.
	 
The contractor will provide year-round recruitment representation in Southeast and South Asia, in Turkey and in Scandinavia. Specifically, he will:
•     Develop relationships for Foothill-De Anza with additional new educational  advising agents;
•     Strengthen  relationships with existing agents;
•     Provide representation  at large study abroad fairs and agent seminars; and
•     Provide ongoing recruitment and international marketing advice.
	 
The contractor will provide these services to Foothill-De Anza and to one or two other institutions, which will equally share in travel and related expenses. He will not represent any other community college.
	 
The contractor will be paid $3,800.00 per month and will invoice us for the District's share of his travel expenses, which will not exceed $95,600.00 for the academic year.
	 
Submitted by:
Kimberlee Messina, Interim President Foothill College
Additional contact names:
Vinita Bali, Dean, International Student Programs

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
George Beers, sole proprietor of Global Enroll, retired from his position as Dean of International Student Programs (ISP) on January 1, 2015.  For approximately 30 years prior to this, he was the principle representative of the District in international markets   Based on his wealth of knowledge of international student  recruitment, the District thought it appropriate to retain him as an independent contractor in 2015-16.  This past year, he provided extensive recruitment services, integrated the new Dean of ISP into the international community, and provided valuable consultation.  For his services in 2015-16, he was paid a salary of $75,000.  His reimbursable expenses were capped at $70,000, for a total contract amount of $145,000 in 2015-16.
	 
In 2016-17, George Beers remains valuable to the District.  He has several relevant contacts in key markets.  He will continue to provide recruitment services in select markets as directed by the ISP staff, continue to transition his valuable contacts to other members of ISP, and provide consultation services as necessary.  For 2016-17, it is proposed that he be retained at a salary of $50,000.  This is a $25,000 reduction in salary as compared to the past year. His reimbursable expenses will similarly be reduced from $70,000 in 2015-16, to $47,000 in 2016-17.  The total reduction in 2016-17, as compared to 2015-16, is $48,000.  This is reflective of the reduced services he will provide as he moves towards a complete transition and termination of his services.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
In February 2016, the De Anza Associated Student Body (DASB) conducted their annual election for the 2016-17 DASB slate of officers and senators. Included in this election was a ballot measure to approve an initiative to support or oppose a $1.34 fee per quarter (adjusted $2 fee for semester) that would support advocacy at the state and local level on issues concerning community college students.  This fee is provided for in State Ed Code section 76061.5.  The students supported the ballot measure with 575 yes votes to 171 opposing (no) votes.
	 
In 2013, the California Education Code 76060.5 was amended to authorize the associated student organization of a community college to hold an election to establish a $2 Student Representation Fee per semester or $1.34 per quarter.  This would allow community college students to advocate for themselves and their communities by providing “support for governmental affairs representatives of local or statewide student body organizations who may be stating their positions and viewpoints before city, county, and district governments, and before offices and agencies of state government” as described in California Education Code 76060.5.  Currently, De Anza College does not have such a fee. The $1.34 fee would be collected each fall, winter and spring quarter and would begin with Fall 2016 quarter.  Students who wish to opt out would use the existing procedures for opting out of voluntary fees.
	 
Submitted by:
 De Anza College President Brian Murphy
Additional contact names:
 Michele LeBleu Burns, ext 881 and John Cognetta, ext 8239

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
On March 10, 2016, the Associated Students of Foothill College (ASFC) Campus Council approved the budget for the fiscal year 2016-2017. Our goal this year was to work towards a more sustainable budget that utilizes our income without relying on our fund balance.
	    
	We strive to allocate funds intelligently and thoughtfully so that Foothill College students can receive quality services, support programs and engaging events. We hope that our efforts translate into the cultivation of a welcoming atmosphere and a positive learning environment. The allocation of funds was discussed with these goals in mind. This year, we were able to re-allocate funds in order to match our income to our expenses more efficiently.
	         
	The manner in which ASFC provides funding to the campus community is determined by matching funding needs to our mission-based vision and goals, which are approved and adopted by members of ASFC every year. We began our process in early Fall. This year, the budget development process went smoothly thanks to the collaborative work done by the budget team.
	 
Submitted by:

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The Administrative Management Association (AMA) and the District have reached a tentative meet-and-confer agreement on the topic of 2015-2016 and 2016-2017 compensation. The Board is hereby requested to approve the 2015-2016 and 2016-2017 compensation changes for Administrators.
	 
The 2015-2016 and 2016-2017 changes regarding compensation and other economic matters include the following:
	 
      Effective July 1, 2015:
o   Salary Schedule:
Salary adjustment of 3.0% (equal to the State-provided 1.02 % COLA plus additional 1.98% adjustment) to the 2014-2015 Administrators Salary Schedule.
o   Adjustment to Step 5, Step 6, Step 7, and Step 8 of the AMA salary schedule, such that each of Steps 5, 6, 7, and 8 shall be 5% above the prior step of the salary schedule.  This reflects an increase from a 3% step-to-step adjustment to a 5% step-to-step adjustment. 
	 
o   Chapter 8.E Educational Stipend
Administrators who successfully complete 36 semester units from an accredited institution subsequent to the attainment of the minimum degree required for his/her position shall be eligible to receive an annual 12-month stipend of $3,384. 
Administrators who successfully complete 72 semester units from an accredited institution subsequent to attainment of the minimum degree required for his/her position shall be eligible to receive a second annual 12-month stipend of $3,384. 
Administrators who earn a doctorate degree from an accredited institution and who are employed in a position requiring a doctorate degree shall be paid an annual stipend of $3,384. 
Administrator shall receive applicable compensation for no more than two stipends at any one time. 
o   Administrative Achievement Awards
Administrative Achievement Award amounts shall be changed as follows:
Award 1 from $3000 to $3000
Award 2 from $3000 to $3750
Award 3 from $3000 to $4250
Award 4 from $3500 to $4500
Total from $12,500 to $15,500
      Effective July 1, 2016:
o   Salary Schedule:
Salary adjustment of 0.60% (equal to the anticipated State-provided 0.47 % COLA plus additional 0.13 % adjustment) to the 2015-2016 Administrators Salary Schedule.
If State COLA is more than 0.60%, the applicable salary adjustment shall be equal to the State-approved cost-of-living adjustment. 
If the state budget includes additional augmentation to the base, the district and AMA agree to resume meet-and-confer discussions.

Background and Analysis:
	 
The existing roofing system for the Campus Center at De Anza College is approximately 18 years old and in need of replacement. This project includes removal of the existing tile roof with underlayment, flashing and sealants and replace with new; removal of existing built up roof assembly at the flat roof and replacing it with a thermoplastic roofing system which includes new insulation; provide new cement plaster system at the parapet structure; repair any substrate dry rot; and replacement of roof hatches and roof ladders. Alternate #1 will replace the worn wood trellis on the south side with a painted metal trellis. 
	 
Allana Buick & Bers Inc. prepared the construction documents and a complete set of all bid documents are on file in the Purchasing Services Department. 
	 
Bid #1746-236G was legally advertised in the San Jose Post Record on February 29 and March 7, 2016, and the bid documents were broadcasted to several contractors and builders exchanges through FHDA’s Purchasing web page.  A mandatory bid walk was held on March 15, 2016, and a total of nine (9) contractors attended the walk.  Bids were publicly opened and read on April 5, 2016, in the Purchasing Services office.  Three (3) contractors submitted a bid and the bid results are summarized below:

Best Contracting Services, Inc. has completed Bid #1120, Building 5100 Roof Replacement at Foothill College; and Project 236E: L2, L3 & L6 Roof Repairs and Project 236F: S4, S5, & L5 Roofing Repairs at De Anza College.

Background and Analysis:
	 
Educational Technology Services (ETS) is in need of purchasing a storage device including maintenance services and the estimated cost will exceed the current statutory bid threshold of $87,800.  The goods and services are necessary to build the Virtualized Desktop Infrastructure (VDI) system for the Foothill College Sunnyvale Campus.  For purchases over the bid threshold, the District must either conduct its own bidding and award process or obtain board authorization to utilize existing contracts awarded by other public entities. This process is commonly known as “piggybacking”. The items required for this purchase by the District are available with the contract’s authorized reseller, Dimension Data.  
	 
It is highly unlikely that a separate bid process conducted by our District would result in more favorable prices, terms, and conditions than the prices offered on the NASPO Master Agreement. 
	 
Measure C will fund the purchase of the storage device, and Fund 14 will be used to cover the cost of the maintenance agreement.  The total cost for the equipment and its maintenance will be $112,912.04.  
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Sharon Luciw, Jose Rueda, Annette Perez
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services, recommends the Board of Trustees make a finding that it is in the best interest of the District to issue purchase orders for goods and services in excess of the legally mandated bid threshold pursuant to Public Contract Code 20652 and the NASPO Master Agreement (MNWNC-125, California Participating Addendum No. 7-15-70-34-019).
